Authors: Mary Catherine Aime, Hector Raul Urbina, Ryoko Oono
Title:
Exabiete hillariae, a new endophytic Atractiellomycetes
isolated from pine needles, and revision of the class
Keywords:
Atractiella, Helicogloeaceae, Hobsonia,
Hoehnelomycetaceae, Leucogloea, orchid mycorrhizae, Phloeogena,
Saccoblastia
Abstract:
The most commonly recovered fungal isolate in a recent
study of needle endophytes of Pinus taeda was an undescribed species of
Atractiellomycetes (Pucciniomycotina, Basidiomycota), a poorly
characterized class of mostly plant-associated presumably saprobic
microfungi. Herein we describe a new species and genus, Exabiete
hillariae (Phleogenaceae, Atractiellales), to accommodate this unusual
species based on morphological characterization and a multilocus
phylogenetic analysis. In culture, E. hillariae produces minute white
sporodochia, similar to those produced by several other members of
Atractiellales, but lacking any teleomorphic characteristics.
Additionally, we provide a taxonomic revision of Atractiellomycetes
based on multi-locus analyses and propose a new genus, Neogloea, to
accommodate ex-Helicogloea species that are congeneric with H.
variabilis. Accumulated evidence suggests Atractiellomycetes species are
common but infrequently isolated members of the plant root and foliar
endobiomes.
